1107109646228021249.text: 15/ If the price of ETH falls, so does the amount of money that goes towards research and development. The future of Ethereum depends on the price of ETH going back up.

1107109644986519554.text: 14/ Also, much of the progress Ethereum has made has been arguably dependent on the price. The price of ETH reflects the future potential of Ethereum, because it could be the programmable reserve currency for the world’s open financial platform.

1107109643539513346.text: 13/ The more value it secures on-chain, the more valuable the token. If validators are leaving Ethereum for other protocols, it decreases the network effect and lowers Ethereum’s security. This encourages people to rally around fewer protocols that are secure.

1107109641907896320.text: 12/ A high price is important in making ETH as secure as possible, because it increases the pool of stakers. The greater the price of ETH, the greater is its network security. The tokens need to be valuable so that more people want to be validators, making it harder to attack.

1107109640490217472.text: 11/ There is a taboo in the Ethereum community to never discuss price and claim that price of ETH and traders doesn’t matter. The reality is that price is vital to the future success of everything being built on Ethereum.

1107109638854447105.text: 10/ Ethereum can’t operate without storing any value in ETH. If ETH is not a SoV, it is likely that another blockchain with a SoV asset at its base layer will beat Ethereum. ETH needs to be a SoV in order to remain competitive as the primary permissionless settlement layer.

1107109637399015425.text: 9/ A threat to ETH being a SoV is something called economic astraction, which is the idea that a different token other than the native token ETH can be used to pay miners. Economic abstraction needs to be killed, making ETH necessary at the base layer.

1107109636035887106.text: 8/ By obtaining these characteristics, ETH will have the framework and potential to be considered a medium of exchange (MoE), unit of account (UoA), and a store of value (SoV).

1107109634597249025.text: 7/ Once proof of stake is implemented on Ethereum and brings the inflation rate of ETH near zero at 0.5%, ETH will have a limited supply, giving it all six characteristics of money: durability, portability, acceptability, divisibility, uniformity, and limited supply.

1107109630830764033.text: 6/ Over the past 3 months, demand for ETH for collateral on platforms like Maker and Compound was 10,000 ETH per day. The natural demand for ETH will soon pass natural supply, making ETH the first cryptocurrency whose available supply is decreasing over time.

1107109629002027008.text: 5/ With Ethereum’s latest Constantinople EIP-1234 upgrade, Ethereum’s block reward was reduced from 3 to 2, reducing inflation of ETH to 4.40%.

1107109626288308229.text: 4/ Supply will decrease as inflation goes down to near 0 in two years, staking is implemented and locks up a substantial amount of the circulating supply of ETH, millions of ETH continues to be used as collateral for Maker CDPs, and locked up in other DeFi apps & DAOs.

1107109624954511365.text: 3/ ETH will also serve as money for three core protocol purposes: gas fees, staking, and storage fees.

1107109623557832706.text: 2/ ETH will accrue more value as demand increases and supply decreases. Demand for ETH will increase because of increased utility for gas, investment due to speculation, and as more DeFi apps gain traction, which promotes the use of ETH as money in the Ethereum economy.

1092572637274861569.text: 9/ Ethereum 1.x also introduces an early version of EWASM that will port the EVM to WebAssembly. EWASM will be much faster than the EVM and people will be able to write Ethereum programs in almost any language.

1092572636125683712.text: 8/ Storage rent will limit the growth of the Ethereum blockchain, and make it possible for users to still run their own full node.

1092572634775150592.text: 7/ A problem with raising the gas limit and increasing transactions is that it will increase the storage size of the blockchain, making it too expensive for users to run a full node. This is why Ethereum 1.x also introduces “storage rent."

1092572633474822144.text: 6/ Ethereum 1.x will reduce the uncle rate, allowing the gas limit to be increased by 2-3x. Increasing the gas limit boosts transaction throughput, allowing more transactions per second on-chain.

1092572632275312641.text: 5/ Uncle blocks don’t affect larger mining pools because they have better odds of propagating blocks. Therefore, if the gas limit is raised, it increases the uncle rate, which results in mining pool centralization, because small mining pools can’t compete.

1092572631176364037.text: 4/ If a block takes too long to propagate, it has a higher chance of becoming an uncle block that is not included in the main chain. These uncle blocks can only receive up to 75% of the original block reward, causing lower revenues for small mining pools.

1092572630161403904.text: 3/ Another upgrade: “Ethereum 1.x” intends to fix block propagation by optimizing the way the Parity client relays blocks.

1092572629016338435.text: 2/ One proposed short-term solution to helping Ethereum scale is a project called Ignis Plasma, which uses a form of cryptography called zk-SNARKs. This will help Ethereum reach 500 transactions per second by aggregating transactions into batches.

1092572626185113600.text:
1/ While we wait for sharding in Ethereum 2.0 (Serenity), there are a couple incremental updates to the Ethereum blockchain being worked on that are expected to increase scalability and performance. 

1)Ignis Plasma
2)Ethereum 1.x

1081378936758591489.text: 16/ Happy New Year! I have a great feeling about Ethereum in 2019.

1081378935168888832.text: 15/ Trustless apps like Augur require a decentralized stablecoin like Dai, which is only created by storing ETH in a Maker CDP. Dai demand increases ETH demand; therefore, the more people use Dai for trustless applications, the bigger Ethereum grows as a trustless economy.

1081378933478612992.text: 14/ Decentralized stablecoins like Maker’s Dai are the future to open finance and increased economic activity on the Ethereum blockchain.

1081378932190961669.text: 13/ Should the collateral not be enough to cover the amount of Dai in existence during a big crash, another token called MKR is created and sold onto the open market in order to raise the additional collateral.

1081378930953601024.text: 12/ If the price of ETH went down, Maker liquidates CDP’s and auctions off the ETH before the value is less than the amount of Dai it is backing.

1081378929644957696.text: 11/ When you lock up ETH in a Maker CDP smart contract, you can create Dai relative to the amount of ETH you put into the CDP. If the price of ETH goes up, the system becomes more collateralized and DAI becomes stronger.

1081378928080576513.text: 10/ The only decentralized stablecoin that currently exists is a collateral-backed stablecoin by Maker called Dai that lives completely on the Ethereum blockchain. The Dai stablecoin is backed by ETH held as collateral in an Ethereum smart contract.

1081378926402842624.text: 9/ This is precisely why decentralized stablecoins are so important, so people can move their dollars, free from controlling hands of government because it is their money.

1081378924913778688.text: 8/ Paxos has already started to withhold funds from users unless they answer questions regarding the source of funds for suspicious transactions. What’s the point of using a stablecoin that doesn’t have finality, isn’t censorship-resistant, or secure?https://www.ccn.com/paxos-standard-hassling-ethereum-traders-trying-to-redeem-stablecoin-pax-for-dollars/ …

1081378923529723904.text: 7/ Unfortunately, they are far from decentralized because there is a backdoor built into these stablecoins that allows addresses to be blacklisted or have funds frozen in order to comply with BSA AML laws, enabling government censorship.

1081378920488886273.text: 6/ These fiat-backed stablecoins are a safer alternative to Tether because they are backed by U.S. dollars held in a bank located in the United States, and are pegged to the dollar on a one-to-one basis. They are also eligible for FDIC insurance and have the backing of the NYDFS.

1081378918773346304.text: 5/ Because of this, regulated fiat-backed stablecoins such as Circle USDC, Paxos, and Gemini Dollar have started gaining traction on major crypto exchanges.

1081378917481500672.text: 4/ Over the past year Tether received a reputation of being untrustworthy because it lost its peg to the US dollar on multiple occasions after widespread fear that it wasn’t allowing third parties to audit its fiat reserves and therefore might be insolvent.

1081378916156137472.text: 3/ Stablecoins will likely replace most utility tokens in the future. The most popular stablecoin over the past few years has been Tether, which has been used as a substitute to fiat on crypto exchanges that don’t have a fiat off-ramp and so people don’t have to switch into fiat.

1081378914327355395.text: 2/ Decentralized stablecoins are important for creating an open financial system and can be used for payments, remittance, and Dapps that require a non-volatile currency that functions as a medium of exchange.

1060665268966322176.text: 11/ This thread was inspired by IDEX adding KYC and blocking NY, the EtherDelta founder being charged by the SEC, and the countless centralized exchange hacks I have seen over the years.

1060665267322183680.text: 10/ Teams around the world are actively working on solving these problems. For the time being, a hybrid DEX that at least offers a trustless non-custodial solution that can’t be hacked will likely become the leading cryptocurrency exchange in the near future.

1060665263928954880.text: 10/ Liquidity, throughput, latency, and high on-chain gas fees in order to post orders seem to be the big problems to solve in order to create a great UX and have fully decentralized exchanges see widespread adoption.

1060665262343544832.text: 9/ The only fully decentralized exchange is OasisDEX, where the trading functionality is entirely on-chain & charges zero fees. Currently, the front-end is open source and can be run locally, but there are plans to move the front end to IPFS. Unfortunately the UX is terrible.

1060665260393160705.text: 8/ Existing cross-chain DEX’s also lack trustless 2-way pegs between chains and instead use trusted 1-way pegs, which they control and can be hacked.

1060665258845528064.text: 7/ Many of these platforms also have a central power that holds the private keys to pseudo smart contract wallets, and can freeze funds if anything goes wrong, which makes them vulnerable to hackers.

1060665257247424512.text: 6/A true DEX should be non-custodial, have decentralized file storage on IPFS instead of AWS, have decentralized DNS on Handshake, not require KYC, not be able to be subpoenaed by governments to block geographic areas or be shut down, and shouldn’t control which coins get listed.

1060665255636819968.text: 5/ The leading DEX’s however have many centralized features; most companies are building hybrid DEX’s (HEX's?), which basically means "non-custodial", because they think it is a “good enough” solution to make a great UX.

1060665253988454401.text: 4/ In a decentralized world, everyone should be in possession of their own private keys. Decentralized exchanges (DEX’s) are a solution to these problems but right now they only make up a small percentage of the trading volume for crypto currencies.

1060665252478517249.text: 3/ CEX's are also overcharging for listings and trading fees and are only listing coins they invested in or have a personal bias towards. A decision from a top exchange to add a token can make or break the value of the token.

1060665250943426560.text: 2/ governments can easily shut them down, and hackers can steal everyone’s tokens if they gained access to the exchange’s private keys. This has already happened numerous times in the past.

1060665232945606657.text:

1049811631331454976.text:
8/ tx fee tradeoff for inflation : 
tx fees were replaced by 5% inflation.
BP's collect 1% of inflation, and 4% goes into the community savings fund. There are 21 active producers which share 50% of the inflation pool. 100 standby producers share the other 50%.

1049811629666328576.text: 7B/ Cartel formation enables them to print money, censor, or reverse transactions. BP’s are accumulating EOS and it gives them a stronger vote over time. It is also possible for exchanges to use their customer’s tokens to vote for delegates.

1049811627531333632.text:
7A/ Cartels:
BP’s are already forming cartels. Cartel formation means the 21 BP’s can form alliances to stay in power by mutually voting for each other in exchange for sharing proceeds.

1049811625757163520.text: 6/ An EOS BP is just a corporate-owned server. It can be shut down with a subpoena or by governments. EOS is not permissionless, immutable, or censorship-resistant.

1049811624318529536.text: 5/ BP’s can agree to reverse transactions, meaning EOS does not have absolute finality and is therefore not Byzantine Fault Tolerant.

1049811622917681154.text: 4B/ The rich buy votes via token accumulation and vote themselves in. It's a plutocracy. Also exchanges are voting with customer funds.

1049811619805581313.text:
4A/ It’s Centralized:
Only 21 BP's that can vote each other in. It takes just 17/21 BP’s to achieve consensus. Blockone, who claimed to have no involvement in the launch of the EOS mainnet are now using the 10% of the token supply they own to influence the list of BP’s.

3A/ Fake tx volume:
Due to the EOS "no transaction fee" model, usage statistics are easily and cheaply manipulated by use of Sybil which fakes Dapp activity and creates the illusion of an active ecosystem.

2/ RAM over-speculation:
It costs up to $17 for users to create an account. Whales cornered the RAM market. RAM is bought up and held by speculators. BP's implemented a constant drip of new RAM. The steadily increasing supply is meant to decrease the demand pressure.
